intro: Monotropastrum globosum var. baranovii, commonly known as the Baranov's moonflower, is a rare and striking plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Onagraceae family and is characterized by its fragrant, white, star-shaped flowers that bloom at night. The plant is a deciduous shrub with opposite, lance-shaped leaves and produces small, fleshy fruits that contain numerous seeds. It thrives in moist, shaded environments, often found in woodland areas with rich, acidic soil. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a conservation concern in some regions.
